title: German submarine U-622
text:
German submarine "U-622" was a <a href="German%20Type%20VIIC%20submarine">Type VIIC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> built for <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" for service during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
She was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 1 July 1941 by <a href="Blohm%20%26amp%3B%20Voss">Blohm & Voss</a>, <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, as yard number 598, <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 19 March 1942 and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 14 May 1942 under "<a href="Oberleutnant%20zur%20See">Oberleutnant zur See</a>" Horst-Thilo Queck.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">German Type VIIC submarines</a> were preceded by the shorter <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIB">Type VIIB submarines</a>. "U-622" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Brown%2C%20Boveri%20%26amp%3B%20Cie">Brown, Boveri & Cie</a> GG UB 720/8 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-622" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, 220 rounds, and a <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> anti-aircraft gun. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between forty-four and sixty.
Service history.
The boat's career began with training at <a href="8th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">8th U-boat Flotilla</a> on 14 May 1942, followed by active service on 1 October 1942 as part of the <a href="11th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">11th Flotilla</a> until 31 May 1943, when she then transferred to <a href="13th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">13th Flotilla</a> on 1 June 1943 for the remainder of her service.
In four patrols she sank no ships.
Wolfpacks.
"U-622" took part in one <a href="Wolfpack%20%28naval%20tactic%29">wolfpack</a>, namely
Fate.
"U-622" was sunk on 24 July 1943 near <a href="Trondheim">Trondheim</a> in position , by American <a href="B-17%20Flying%20Fortress">B-17 bombers</a> of the <a href="95th%20Bomb%20Group">95th Bomb Group</a>. It was one of the only U-boats sunk by high-level bombing during World War II.
